description: From Middle English lightsum, equivalent to light (“bright”, adjective) +‎ -some (“very like, same as”, suffix forming adjectives).

adjectives.description:
lightsome (comparative more lightsome, superlative most lightsome)
(literary)

entries.meaning: Characterised by light; luminous; emitting or manifesting light; radiant.
examples: This said, the smoky cloud was cleft and torn, / Which like a veil upon them stretched lay, // And up to open heav'n forthwith was borne, / And left the prince in view of lightsome day.

description: From light (“not heavy”, adjective) +‎ -some (“very like, same as”, suffix forming adjectives).

adjectives.description: lightsome (comparative more lightsome, superlative most lightsome)

entries.meaning: Characterised by lightness of weight, not heavy; nimble, active.

examples: Reality is lightsome, that is, light and graceful.... Moreover, the play, the lightsome character of reality, would be misunderstood if this dimension were to be severed from what really makes a play a play, [...]
